Goals for Chapter 44 • To learn the key varieties of fundamental particles • To see how accelerators and detectors are used to investigate subatomic particles • To learn how subatomic particles interact with each other • To understand how quarks explain the structure of many subatomic particles • To learn how we probe the standard model of particles and interactions • To investigate the Big Bang and the expansion of the universe Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. Introduction • How much of the universe is composed of “normal” matter? • What is the world ultimately made of? • The physics on the microscopic scale is essential to understand the universe on its largest scale. • We’ll conclude with the evolution of the universe. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. Particles and interactions • The four fundamental interactions (forces) are:  the strong interaction  the electromagnetic interaction  the weak interaction  the gravitational interaction. • Table 44.1 summarizes characteristics of these interactions. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. Leptons • Leptons do not experience the strong interaction. • Table 44.2 summarizes the characteristics of the six leptons. • Follow Example 44.4. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. Hadrons • Hadrons experience the strong interaction. • Mesons and baryons are subclasses of hadrons. • Table 44.3 (next slide) shows some hadrons and their properties. • The total baryon number is conserved in all interactions. • Follow the text discussion of hadrons, strangeness, and conservation laws. • Follow Example 44.5. • Follow Example 44.6. The expanding universe • There is a red shift in the light from distant galaxies. • Hubble’s law: The recession speed of a galaxy is proportional to its distance r from us: v = H0r. • The graph in Figure 44.16 (right) illustrates Hubble’s law. • Follow Example 44.8. • Follow Example 44.9. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. The Big Bang • Hubble’s law suggests that at one time all the matter in the universe was extremely concentrated and was then blown apart by the Big Bang. • The red shift of galaxies is caused by the expansion of space itself. We live in an expanding universe. • Figure 44.17 (right) shows an analogy for the expanding universe. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc. The future of the universe • If the average density of the universe is less than the critical density, the universe should expand forever. If it is greater, the universe should stop expanding and then contract. (See Figure 44.18 at the right.) • Most of the matter in the universe is mysterious nonluminous dark matter. • Invisible dark energy seems to be causing the expansion of the universe to speed up. Copyright © 2012 Pearson Education Inc.
